title: Java Virtual Machine (JVM)
description: The JVM is the engine that drives the Java code. It converts Java bytecode into machine language. The JVM enables Java's 'Write Once, Run Anywhere' capability by providing a platform-independent execution environment.

title: Java Object-Oriented Programming
description: Java is a class-based, object-oriented programming language. It adheres to the four main principles of OOP: Encapsulation, Inheritance, Polymorphism, and Abstraction. Everything in Java is associated with classes and objects.

title: Java Primitive Data Types
description: Java define 8 primitive data types: byte, short, int, long, float, double, boolean, and char. These are not objects and are stored directly in the stack memory for efficiency. Wrapper classes exist to treat them as objects.

title: Java Garbage Collection
description: Java provides automatic garbage collection, which identifies and discards objects that are no longer needed by the program to free up memory resources. The JVM's Garbage Collector runs in the background.

title: Java Collections Framework
description: The Collections Framework provides a set of interfaces and classes to store and manipulate groups of data. Key interfaces include List, Set, Queue, and Map. Implementations include ArrayList, HashSet, LinkedList, and HashMap.

title: Java Multithreading
description: Java supports multithreading, allowing concurrent execution of two or more parts of a program. Threads can be created by extending the Thread class or implementing the Runnable interface. Synchronization is used to prevent race conditions.

title: Java Streams API
description: Introduced in Java 8, the Streams API is used to process sequences of elements. It supports functional-style operations on streams of elements, such as map-reduce transformations on collections.

title: Java Exception Handling
description: Java uses a robust exception handling mechanism based on try, catch, finally, throw, and throws keywords. It distinguishes between checked exceptions (compile-time) and unchecked exceptions (runtime).

title: Spring Framework
description: Spring is a powerful, lightweight framework for enterprise Java development. It provides comprehensive infrastructure support including Dependency Injection (DI) and Aspect-Oriented Programming (AOP).

title: Java Access Modifiers
description: Access modifiers determine the scope of classes, variables, methods, and constructors. The four levels are: public (visible to all), protected (package + subclasses), default (package only), and private (class only).

title: Java Generics
description: Generics enable types (classes and interfaces) to be parameters when defining classes, interfaces, and methods. They provide stronger type checks at compile time and eliminate the need for casting.

title: Java Interfaces
description: An interface is a reference type in Java, similar to a class, that can contain only constants, method signatures, default methods, and static methods. Use abstract classes when you need to share code, interface to define a contract.

title: Java Reflection API
description: Reflection is a feature that allows a program to examine or modify the runtime behavior of applications running in the JVM. It allows inspection of classes, interfaces, fields and methods at runtime.

title: Maven
description: Maven is a build automation tool used primarily for Java projects. It addresses two aspects of building software: how software is built, and its dependencies. It uses an XML file (pom.xml) for configuration.

title: Hibernate
description: Hibernate is an Object-Relational Mapping (ORM) framework for Java. It simplifies the development of Java application to interact with the database. It maps Java classes to database tables and Java data types to SQL data types.

title: Java Lambda Expressions
description: Introduced in Java 8, Lambda expressions provide a clear and concise way to represent one method interface using an expression. They are useful in collection library and define inline implementation of a functional interface.

title: Java String Pool
description: The String Pool is a special storage area in the Java heap. When a string is created and if the string already exists in the pool, the reference of the existing string will be returned, instead of creating a new object, saving memory.

title: Java Annotations
description: Annotations provide metadata about the program that is not part of the program itself. They have no direct effect on the operation of the code they annotate. They are used for compile-time checks (e.g., @Override) or runtime processing.

title: Gradle
description: Gradle is an open-source build automation system that builds upon the concepts of Apache Ant and Apache Maven and introduces a Groovy-based domain-specific language (DSL) instead of the XML form used by Apache Maven.

title: JDK vs JRE vs JVM
description: JDK (Java Development Kit) contains tools for developers (javac). JRE (Java Runtime Environment) contains libraries and JVM to run programs. JVM (Java Virtual Machine) executes the bytecode. JDK > JRE > JVM.

title: Java Serialization
description: Serialization is a mechanism of converting the state of an object into a byte stream. Deserialization is the reverse process. It is used to persist the object state or to travel the object over a network. Classes must implement Serializable interface.

title: Singleton Pattern in Java
description: Singleton is a design pattern that prevents the instantiation of a class to more than one object. In Java, this is often implemented with a private constructor and a static method that returns the single instance.

title: Java Servlets
description: Servlets are Java programs that run on a Web server, acting as a middle layer between a request coming from a Web browser or other HTTP client and databases or applications on the HTTP server.

title: Java Enums
description: An Enum is a special data type which enables for a variable to be a set of predefined constants. The variable must be equal to one of the values that have been predefined for it. Enums can also have fields, methods, and constructors.

title: Java Volatile Keyword
description: The volatile keyword is used to indicate that a variable's value will be modified by different threads. It ensures that the value of the volatile variable will always be read from the main memory and not from the thread's local cache.

title: JUnit
description: JUnit is a unit testing framework for the Java programming language. It is important in the test-driven development aspect of programming. It allows developers to write and run repeatable tests.

title: Java Static Keyword
description: The static keyword is used for memory management mainly. It can apply to variables, methods, blocks, and nested classes. The static keyword belongs to the class than an instance of the class.

title: Java Final Keyword
description: The final keyword is a non-access modifier used to restrict the user. A final variable cannot be changed (constant), a final method cannot be overridden, and a final class cannot be inherited.

title: Java This Keyword
description: There is a 'this' keyword in Java that is a reference variable that refers to the current object. It can be used to refer to current class instance variable, invoke current class method, or invoke current class constructor.

title: Java Super Keyword
description: The super keyword is a reference variable which is used to refer to immediate parent class object. It is used to invoke parent class methods, constructors, and access parent class variables.

title: Java Optional Class
description: Introduced in Java 8, Optional is a container object used to contain not-null objects. Optional object is used to represent null with absent value. It provides various utility methods to facilitate code to handle values as 'available' or 'not available' instead of checking null values.

title: JSP (JavaServer Pages)
description: JSP is a technology used to develop software to support dynamic content based on HTML, XML, or other document types. It helps developers to insert Java code in HTML pages by making use of special JSP tags.

title: Java Arrays
description: An array is a container object that holds a fixed number of values of a single type. The length of an array is established when the array is created. After creation, its length is fixed.

title: Java Functional Interfaces
description: A functional interface is an interface that contains only one abstract method. They can have any number of default, static methods but can contain only one abstract method. They are the basis for Lambda expressions.

title: Java JAR Files
description: JAR (Java ARchive) is a package file format typically used to aggregate many Java class files and associated metadata and resources (text, images, etc.) into one file for distribution.

title: Spring Boot
description: Spring Boot is an extension of the Spring Framework that simplifies the setup and development of new Spring applications. It takes an opinionated view of the Spring platform which keeps boilerplate code and configuration to a minimum.

title: IntelliJ IDEA
description: IntelliJ IDEA is an integrated development environment (IDE) written in Java for developing computer software. It is developed by JetBrains and is considered one of the best IDEs for Java development with smart code completion and analysis.

title: Java Networking (Socket Programming)
description: Java Networking is a concept of connecting two or more computing devices together so that we can share resources. Java provides java.net package to perform networking details. Socket programming provides a mechanism for communication between two computers using TCP.

title: Java Packages
description: A java package is a group of similar types of classes, interfaces and sub-packages. Packages are used to categorize the classes and interfaces to be easily maintained and also provide access protection and namespace management.

title: Java NIO (New I/O)
description: Java NIO is a comprehensive I/O framework introduced in Java 1.4. It offers a different way of working with I/O than the standard I/O API's. NIO supports buffers, channels, and non-blocking I/O operations.

title: Java Constructors
description: A constructor in Java is a special method that is used to initialize objects. The constructor is called when an object of a class is created. It can be used to set initial values for object attributes.

title: Java Polymorphism (Runtime vs Compile-time)
description: Polymorphism allows objects to act differently based on their specific class. Compile-time polymorphism is achieved via method overloading, while runtime polymorphism is achieved via method overriding.

title: Java ClassLoader
description: The Java ClassLoader is a part of the Java Runtime Environment that dynamically loads Java classes into the Java Virtual Machine. Usually, classes are only loaded on demand. The Java run time system does not need to know about files and file systems because of class loaders.

title: Java Abstract Classes
description: An abstract class is a class that is declared with the abstract keyword. It may or may not have abstract methods. Abstract classes cannot be instantiated, but they can be subclassed.

title: Jakarta EE (formerly Java EE)
description: Jakarta EE is a set of specifications, extending Java SE with specifications for enterprise features such as distributed computing and web services. It manages the standard for enterprise-grade applications.

title: Log4j
description: Log4j is a reliable, fast and flexible logging framework (APIs) written in Java, which is distributed under the Apache Software License. It is used to log messages to various output targets.

title: Java Wrapper Classes
description: Wrapper classes provide a way to use primitive data types (int, boolean, etc.) as objects. This is necessary when working with Collection frameworks, which only work with objects.

title: Java Record Classes
description: Introduced in Java 14/16, Records are a special kind of class in Java that acts as a transparent carrier for immutable data. Records reduce boilerplate code by automatically generating constructor, getters, equals, hashCode, and toString.

title: Java Module System (Jigsaw)
description: Introduced in Java 9, the module system allows grouping related packages and resources into modules. It improves encapsulation and allows the JVM to be more modular and lightweight.

title: Apache Tomcat
description: Apache Tomcat is an open-source implementation of the Java Servlet, JavaServer Pages, Java Expression Language and Java WebSocket technologies. It acts as a web server and servlet container for Java web applications.
